At the risk of leaving someone out, I thank Deborah Appleman, Brigid Barron, Eric Beckman, Stephen Bloch-Schulman, Lendol Calder, Scott Casper, Mike Caulfield, Larry Cuban, John Findlay, Ed Haertel, Jonah Hassenfeld, Michelle Herczog, Brian Johnsrud, Greg Kaster, Michael Kazin, Harvey Klehr, Gary Kornblith, Michael Kort, Jill Lepore, Rachel Lotan, Daisy Martin, Tracy McKenzie, Chauncey Monte-Sano, Walter Parker, Howard Rheingold, Dan Russell, Jack Schneider, Simone Schweber, Rich Shavelson, Eric Shed, Mark Smith, Luther Spoehr, Cathy Taylor, David Thelen, Laura Westhoff, Dan Willingham, and Anat Zohar.

ç‰¹åˆ«æ„Ÿè°¢çŽ›ä¸½Â·ç‘žå®‰ï¼Œå¥¹å‹¤æ³åœ°æ ¡å¯¹äº†æœ¬ä¹¦ï¼ˆä»¥åŠæˆ‘è¿‡åŽ»äºŒåå¹´æ¥å‡ ä¹Žæ‰€æœ‰ä½œå“ï¼‰ï¼Œå¹¶æ•™ä¼šäº†æˆ‘è®¸å¤šå†™ä½œæŠ€å·§ã€‚æˆ‘çš„æœ¬ç§‘ç ”ç©¶åŠ©ç†çå¨œÂ·åŠ ç™»åƒçŒ«å¤´é¹°ä¸€æ ·è­¦è§‰ï¼Œå‘çŽ°äº†è®¸å¤šçœ¼å…‰æ•é”çš„äººéƒ½å¿½ç•¥çš„é”™è¯¯ã€‚æˆ‘è‹¦è‹¦æ€ç´¢æœ¬ä¹¦çš„æ ¸å¿ƒè®ºç‚¹æ—¶ï¼Œç‘žç§‹Â·å›¾å°”ï¼ˆRachel Toorï¼‰å°±åƒå¤©ä½¿ä¸€èˆ¬å‡ºçŽ°äº†ã€‚ä¹”å°”Â·å¸ƒé›·å…‹æ–¯é€šï¼ˆJoel Breakstoneï¼‰ã€è‰¾æ¯”Â·é›·æ–¯æ›¼ï¼ˆAbby Reismanï¼‰å’ŒèŽŽæ‹‰Â·éº¦æ ¼é²ï¼ˆSarah McGrewï¼‰æ€»æ˜¯æ”¾ä¸‹æ‰‹å¤´çš„ä¸€åˆ‡ï¼ŒåŠæ—¶å›žå¤æˆ‘é‚£äº›æ€¥åˆ‡çš„â€œæ€¥éœ€å¿«é€Ÿé˜…è¯»â€é‚®ä»¶ã€‚ä»–ä»¬çœŸæ˜¯è®©æˆ‘ä½©æœå¾—äº”ä½“æŠ•åœ°ã€‚æˆ‘çš„ç¼–è¾‘ä¼Šä¸½èŽŽç™½Â·å¸ƒå…°å¥‡Â·æˆ´æ£®ï¼ˆElizabeth Branch Dysonï¼‰å¹¶ä¸çŸ¥é“ï¼Œåœ¨æˆ‘æƒè¡¡å„ç§é‚€çº¦æ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»Žæœªæ€€ç–‘è¿‡ä¼šé€‰æ‹©èŠåŠ å“¥å¤§å­¦å‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾ã€‚ä»Žæˆ‘ä»¬è§é¢çš„é‚£ä¸€åˆ»èµ·ï¼Œå¥¹é‚£è€€çœ¼çš„æ‰åŽå°±æ·±æ·±å¸å¼•äº†æˆ‘ã€‚æˆ‘åˆ«æ— é€‰æ‹©ï¼Œåªæƒ³è®©å¥¹æ‹…ä»»æˆ‘çš„ç¼–è¾‘ã€‚è‰¾ç³Â·å¾·å¨ç‰¹ï¼ˆErin DeWittï¼‰å¯¹ç¨¿ä»¶çš„æ ¡å¯¹ç»†è‡´å…¥å¾®ï¼Œç®€ç›´è¶…å‡¡è„±ä¿—ã€‚æˆ‘ç”±è¡·åœ°æ„Ÿè°¢å¥¹ã€‚

Special thanks go to Mary Ryan, who diligently copyedited this volume (as well as pretty much everything Iâ€™ve written over the past twenty years) and taught me as much about writing as anyone. With owl-like vigilance, my undergraduate research assistant, Jenna Garden, swooped up errors that escaped many a discerning eye. As I struggled to formulate this bookâ€™s main argument, an angel in the guise of Rachel Toor appeared. Joel Breakstone, Abby Reisman, and Sarah McGrew unfailingly dropped everything to respond to my harried â€œQuick Read Neededâ€ emails. They amaze me. My editor, Elizabeth Branch Dyson, had no idea that when I was weighing different offers, I never doubted I would sign with Chicago. From the moment we met, she captivated me with her incandescent intelligence. I wanted no one else as my editor. Erin DeWitt copyedited this manuscript with an attention to detail that can only be described as otherworldly. I am supremely grateful.

ç¬¬ä¸ƒç« çš„å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†å†…å®¹æ˜¯ä¸Žæ˜Œè¥¿Â·è’™ç‰¹-è¨è¯ºï¼ˆChauncey Monte-Sanoï¼‰åˆè‘—çš„ï¼Œæœ€åˆå‘è¡¨äºŽã€Šç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²æ‚å¿—ã€‹ï¼ˆJournal of American Historyï¼‰ã€‚è¿™é¡¹ç ”ç©¶æœ€åˆæºäºŽæˆ‘ä¸Žè‰¾ç‘žå°”Â·é‚“è‚¯ï¼ˆAriel Duncanï¼‰çš„ä¸€æ¬¡è°ˆè¯ï¼Œå½“æ—¶å¥¹æ­£å€¼å¥¥æŸæž—å­¦é™¢äºŒå¹´çº§ä¼‘å­¦ï¼Œåœ¨æˆ‘è¿™é‡Œæ‹…ä»»ç ”ç©¶åŠ©ç†ï¼Œåº¦è¿‡äº†ä¸€æ®µéš¾å¿˜çš„æ—¶å…‰ã€‚è‡ªé‚£ä»¥åŽï¼Œå¥¹ä¸€ç›´æ˜¯æˆ‘çš„æŒšå‹ã€‚å¦‚æžœæ²¡æœ‰ç½—ä¼ŠÂ·ç½—æ£®èŒ¨å¨æ ¼ï¼ˆRoy Rosenzweigï¼‰çš„æ”¯æŒï¼Œè¿™é¡¹ç ”ç©¶æ°¸è¿œæ— æ³•å®Œæˆã€‚ä»–çš„è‹±å¹´æ—©é€ä»¤æˆ‘ä»¬è®¸å¤šäººå¿ƒç—›ä¸å·²ã€‚

Substantial parts of chapter 7 were co-written with Chauncey Monte-Sano and appeared first in the Journal of American History. That study started as a wisp of an idea in a conversation with Ariel Duncan, who while on leave from her sophomore year at Oberlin spent an unforgettable month with me as a research assistant. She has been a dear friend ever since. The study would never have come to completion without the support of Roy Rosenzweig, whose untimely death left a hole in so many of our hearts.

ä¸€ä½æœ‰å¹¸çš„å­¦è€…ä¸€ç”Ÿéƒ½ä¸Žä¸€ç¾¤å¿—åŒé“åˆçš„äººåŒè¡Œã€‚æˆ‘æœ€ä¿¡ä»»çš„ä¼™ä¼´æ˜¯å½¼å¾—Â·å¡žå…‹æ–¯å’Œé²å‹ƒÂ·è´æ©ï¼Œä»–ä»¬å‡ ä¹Žé˜…è¯»ã€è®¨è®ºå¹¶åé©³äº†æœ¬ä¹¦ä¸­çš„æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªè§‚ç‚¹ã€‚æˆ‘ä¸Žé»›æ¯”Â·å…‹å¾·æ›¼çš„å‹è°Šæ˜¯æˆ‘æœ€å¤è€ã€æœ€çè´µçš„å‹è°Šä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚åœ¨CERAS 503å·çš„â€œå·¢ç©´â€é‡Œï¼Œæˆ‘è’™å—ç€ä¸¤ä½æ‰æ™ºç›¸æŠ•çš„å§å¦¹â€”â€”å¸•å§†Â·æ ¼ç½—æ–¯æ›¼å’Œè‹çŠå¨œÂ·å¨å°”é€Šâ€”â€”çš„çˆ±ï¼Œå¥¹ä»¬ä»Žæœªå¿˜è®°æˆ‘ä»¬ä¹‹é—´çš„äº²æƒ…çº½å¸¦ï¼Œä¹Ÿä»Žæœªå¿˜è®°æˆ‘ä»¬å¯¹æ©å¸ˆæŽÂ·èˆ’å°”æ›¼çš„æ„Ÿæ¿€ä¹‹æƒ…ã€‚

A fortunate scholar moves through life with a pack. My trusted pack members are Peter Seixas and Bob Bain, both of whom have read, discussed, and disputed nearly every idea contained herein. My friendship with Debby Kerdeman is one of my oldest and most cherished. From our nest in 503 CERAS, Iâ€™ve been blessed by the love of my two intellectual sisters, Pam Grossman and Suzanne Wilson, whoâ€™ve never forgotten our familial bond and debt we owe to our teacher Lee Shulman.

æœ¬ä¹¦å»ºç«‹åœ¨æ•°åå¹´çš„å®žéªŒå’Œå®žåœ°ç ”ç©¶ä¹‹ä¸Šï¼Œè€Œè¿™ä¸€åˆ‡éƒ½ç¦»ä¸å¼€é‚£äº›ä¿¡ä»»æˆ‘çš„äººä»¬çš„æ…·æ…¨æ”¯æŒã€‚å®‰å¦®Â·æ°æ›¼çº³ç§‘æ–¯æ¯”æˆ‘æ›´æ—©æ„è¯†åˆ°ï¼Œäº’è”ç½‘å¯¹å…¬æ°‘èº«ä»½æž„æˆçš„å¨èƒå‰æ‰€æœªæœ‰ã€‚è²å°”Â·å“ˆå°”ç€æž—ã€å¨œå¡”èŽŽÂ·éœæ©å’Œæœ±èŽ‰Â·åŸºå¾·ä¸ä»…æ”¯æŒäº†è¿™é¡¹å·¥ä½œï¼Œè¿˜æé†’æˆ‘ï¼Œå­¦è€…çš„è´£ä»»å¹¶ä¸æ­¢äºŽå‘è¡¨ä¸€ç¯‡åŒè¡Œè¯„å®¡çš„æœŸåˆŠæ–‡ç« ã€‚çå¦®Â·å´”ã€è‚–æ©Â·å¸Œåˆ©ä»¥åŠä»–ä»¬åœ¨ç½—ä¼¯ç‰¹Â·RÂ·éº¦è€ƒå¯†å…‹åŸºé‡‘ä¼šçš„åŒäº‹ä»¬ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰è‰¾ç±³Â·å¾·é›·ã€ç½—è¾¾Â·å¼—é‡Œéš†ã€æˆ´å®‰å¨œÂ·èµ«æ–¯ã€ä¹”Â·å¡æ©ä»¥åŠä»–ä»¬åœ¨æ–¯å®¾å¡žåŸºé‡‘ä¼šçš„åŒäº‹ä»¬ï¼Œéƒ½åœ¨æˆ‘äººç”Ÿçš„å…³é”®æ—¶åˆ»ç»™äºˆäº†æˆ‘å¸®åŠ©ã€‚è–‡è–‡å®‰è¿‡åŽ»åå¹´é—´ï¼Œé˜¿ç©†ç±³å’ŒæŽå®‰Â·æ³¢ç‰¹å¤«å¦‡ä»¥åŠç¾Žå›½å›½ä¼šå›¾ä¹¦é¦†â€œåˆ©ç”¨åŽŸå§‹èµ„æ–™è¿›è¡Œæ•™å­¦è”ç›Ÿâ€çš„æˆå‘˜ä¸€ç›´æ˜¯å€¼å¾—ä¿¡èµ–çš„å­¦æœ¯ä¼™ä¼´ã€‚å¨å»‰å’Œå¼—æ´›æ‹‰Â·ä¼‘åˆ©ç‰¹åŸºé‡‘ä¼šçš„é©¬å…‹Â·æ˜¥ä¸€ç›´ä¸é—ä½™åŠ›åœ°æ¿€åŠ±æˆ‘ä»¬çš„ç ”ç©¶å›¢é˜Ÿæ‹“å±•æ€ç»´ï¼Œè¿½æ±‚æ›´é«˜çš„ç›®æ ‡ã€‚

This book rests on decades of experimental and field-based research, none of which could have been done without the generous support of those who put their faith in me. Anne Germanacos recognized before I did that the Internet posed a threat to citizenship like no other. Phil Halperin, Natasha Hoehn, and Julie Kidd not only supported this work, but reminded me that a scholarâ€™s obligation does not end with a refereed journal article. Jenny Choi, Shawn Healy, and their colleagues at the Robert R. McCormick Foundation came into my life at a critical juncture, as did Amy Dray, Rhoda Freelon, Diana Hess, Joe Kahne, and their colleagues at the Spencer Foundation. Vivian Amumey and Lee Ann Potter and the members of the Teaching with Primary Source Consortium at the Library of Congress have been trusted intellectual partners over the past decade. Marc Chun at the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation has been unyielding in prodding our research group to think bigger and aim higher.

ç¬¬å…­ç« çš„çµæ„ŸæºäºŽæˆ‘åœ¨é›·éœæ²ƒç‰¹ä¸»å¹²é“ä¸Šçš„Loolå’–å•¡é¦†ä¸€è¾¹å•œé¥®å’–å•¡ä¸€è¾¹åœ¨ç¬”è®°æœ¬ä¸Šéšæ‰‹å†™ä¸‹çš„é›¶æ•£ç¬”è®°ã€‚æˆ‘çš„è°ˆè¯å¯¹è±¡æ˜¯æˆ‘çš„æŒšå‹å…¼åˆè‘—è€…åŸƒåˆ©Â·æˆˆç‰¹åˆ©å¸ƒã€‚ä½œä¸ºè€¶è·¯æ’’å†·æ›¼å¾·å°”åŸºé‡‘ä¼šçš„å‰¯æ€»è£ï¼ŒåŸƒåˆ©ä¸€ç›´é¼“åŠ±æˆ‘åœ¨æœ¬ä¹¦çš„æž„æ€å°šæœªå®Œå…¨æˆç†Ÿä¹‹å‰å°±å°†å…¶åˆç¨¿å‘ˆçŽ°ç»™å¤§å®¶ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”å§‹ç»ˆä¿æŒç€æ¸©å’Œçš„æ‰¹è¯„å’Œæ— æ¡ä»¶çš„é¼ŽåŠ›æ”¯æŒã€‚æ›¼å¾·å°”åŸºé‡‘ä¼šç»™äº†æˆ‘ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªèŒä¸šå½’å®¿ã€‚æˆ‘è¡·å¿ƒæ„Ÿè°¢èŽ«é¡¿Â·æ›¼å¾·å°”ã€è€¶èƒ¡è¾¾Â·èŽ±å› å“ˆèŒ¨å’Œæ‘©è¥¿Â·ç»´æ ¼å¤šåœ¨è¿‡åŽ»äºŒåå¹´é‡Œå¯¹æˆ‘çš„çƒ­æƒ…æ¬¾å¾…ã€‚ä»Žæ–°åƒå¹´ä¼Šå§‹ä¸¹å°¼å°”Â·é©¬ç½—å§†å¸¦æˆ‘åŽ»é›†å¸‚åƒåˆé¥­ï¼Œåˆ°æˆ‘ä»¬æ¯ä¸¤å¹´åœ¨ä¼ŠçŽ›é¤åŽ…çš„èšé¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸€ç›´æ˜¯çŸ¥å·±ã€è¾©è®ºä¼™ä¼´å’ŒæŒšå‹ã€‚æ­£æ˜¯é€šè¿‡ä»–çš„â€œè¯¾å ‚ä¸Šçš„å…‹é‡Œå¥¥â€é¡¹ç›®ï¼Œæˆ‘ç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¡è®¤è¯†äº†æŸ¥ç“¦Â·æ²™æ©ï¼Œå¥¹åŽæ¥æˆä¸ºæˆ‘çš„åšå£«ç”Ÿå¯¼å¸ˆï¼Œå¹¶æœ€ç»ˆæ•™ä¼šäº†æˆ‘ã€Šå¡”å®‰å°¼ç‰¹ã€‹ 7a çš„å«ä¹‰ã€‚åœ¨æ›¼å¾·å°”å­¦é™¢çš„è¿™äº›å¹´é‡Œï¼Œå®‰å¦®ç‰¹å’Œç»å°”Â·éœèµ«æ–¯å¦å¤«å¦‡æžå¤§åœ°ä¸°å¯Œäº†æˆ‘çš„ç”Ÿæ´»ï¼Œä»–ä»¬çš„æ…·æ…¨æ— ç§ä»¤äººæ•¬ä½©ã€‚

Chapter 6 started out as scattered jottings in my notebook while sipping coffee at Lool, on Rehovotâ€™s main thoroughfare. My conversation partner was my close friend and coauthor Eli Gottlieb. As vice president of Jerusalemâ€™s Mandel Foundation, Eli has encouraged me to present the first drafts of the ideas in this book before they were ready for prime time, and he has remained gently critical and unqualifiedly supportive throughout. The Mandel Foundation has given me a second professional home. I thank Morton Mandel, Jehuda Reinharz, and Moshe Vigdor for the welcome mat they have extended over the past two decades. From the moment Daniel Marom took me to lunch in the shuk in the first year of the new millennium to our bi-yearly dinners at Ima, weâ€™ve been confidants, sparring partners, and the best of friends. It was through his project, Clio in the Classroom, that I first met Chava Shane, who later became my doctoral advisee and ultimately taught me the meaning of Taâ€™annit 7a. In my years at Mandel, my life has been enriched by Annette and Shaul Hochstein, whose generosity knows no bounds.

æˆ‘çš„å¦»å­è‹çŠÂ·èŽ«çº³æ–¯ä¸€ç›´æ˜¯æˆ‘æœ€ä¿¡ä»»çš„è¯»è€…ï¼Œå¥¹å¯¹å­¦æœ¯ä¸Šçš„æµ®å¤¸å’Œè¯­è¨€ä¸Šçš„çŸ«æ‰é€ ä½œæ¯«ä¸å®¹å¿ã€‚å¥¹æ•é”çš„æ–‡é‡‡ä½¿è¯»è€…å…å—äº†è®¸å¤šä¸å’Œè°éŸ³çš„å¹²æ‰°ã€‚æˆ‘çš„å¼Ÿå¼Ÿé²å‹ƒåœ¨æˆ‘äººç”Ÿçš„é¡ºå¢ƒå’Œé€†å¢ƒä¸­å§‹ç»ˆåšå®šåœ°é™ªä¼´åœ¨æˆ‘èº«è¾¹ã€‚æˆ‘çš„ä¸‰ä¸ªå­©å­ï¼Œè‚–èŽŽå¨œã€è¿ˆå…‹å°”å’Œæ‹‰æ–å°”ï¼Œåœ¨æˆ‘äººç”ŸåŠ¨è¡æ—¶æœŸå°±åƒåšå®žçš„æ”¯æŸ±ï¼Œä»–ä»¬æ€»æ˜¯åœ¨æˆ‘èº«è¾¹ï¼Œæ€»æ˜¯æ„¿æ„å€¾å¬ï¼Œæ€»æ˜¯åœ¨æˆ‘éœ€è¦ä»–ä»¬çš„æ—¶å€™å›žå®¶ï¼Œæ€»æ˜¯æ„¿æ„è®©ä»–ä»¬çš„çˆ¶äº²åœ¨æˆ‘æ‘‡æ‘‡æ¬²å ã€å‡ ä¹Žç«™ä¸ç¨³çš„æ—¶å€™ä¾é ä»–ä»¬ã€‚æˆ‘çš„å°å…¬ä¸»å’Œä¸¤ä¸ªå®è´æ˜¯æˆ‘æœ€å¤§çš„ç¦æ°”ã€‚

My wife, Susan Monas, has always been my most trusted reader, showing little tolerance for academic bombast and linguistic posturing. Her keen ear for prose has saved readers from many discordant notes. My brother Bob has steadfastly stood by my side through times good and bad. My three children, Shoshana, Michael, and Raphael, have been unmovable pillars during times of turbulence, always there, always willing to listen, always willing to come home when I needed them, always willing to let their father lean on them when he was teetering and could barely stand. My princess and two treasures are my greatest blessings.

CHAPTER ONE

1æœ¬ç« éƒ¨åˆ†å†…å®¹æœ€åˆå‘è¡¨äºŽ Sam Wineburgï¼Œâ€œCrazy for Historyâ€ï¼Œã€Šç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 90 (2004): 1401â€“14ï¼›J. Carleton Bell å’Œ David F. McCollumï¼Œâ€œA Study of the Attainments of Pupils in United States Historyâ€ï¼Œã€Šæ•™è‚²å¿ƒç†å­¦æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 8 (1917 å¹´ 5 æœˆ): 257â€“58ã€‚

1 Portions of this chapter originally appeared as Sam Wineburg, â€œCrazy for History,â€ Journal of American History 90 (2004): 1401â€“14; J. Carleton Bell and David F. 2 Bell å’Œ McCollumï¼Œâ€œç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²å­¦ç”Ÿæˆç»©ç ”ç©¶â€ï¼Œç¬¬ 268-269 é¡µã€‚äº”å¹´åŽï¼ŒBell å’Œ McCollum çš„è°ƒæŸ¥è¢«é‡å¤è¿›è¡Œï¼Œä½†è§„æ¨¡å°å¾—å¤šã€‚å‚è§ DH Eikenberryï¼Œâ€œé«˜ä¸­å­¦ä¹ çš„æŒä¹…æ€§â€ï¼Œã€Šæ•™è‚²å¿ƒç†å­¦æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 14ï¼ˆ1923 å¹´ 11 æœˆï¼‰ï¼š463-481ã€‚å¦è§ Garry C. 3æœ¬æ°æ˜ŽÂ·èŠ¬æ©ï¼Œã€Šå¤§å­¦æ–°ç”Ÿå¯¹ç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²çš„æ— çŸ¥ã€‹ï¼Œã€Šçº½çº¦æ—¶æŠ¥ã€‹ï¼Œ1943å¹´4æœˆ4æ—¥ï¼Œç¬¬1é¡µï¼›è‰¾ä¼¦Â·å†…æ–‡æ–¯ï¼Œã€Šç¾Žå›½äººçš„ç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²ã€‹ï¼Œã€Šçº½çº¦æ—¶æŠ¥æ‚å¿—ã€‹ï¼Œ1942å¹´5æœˆ3æ—¥ï¼Œç¬¬6é¡µå’Œç¬¬28é¡µã€‚ã€Šçº½çº¦æ—¶æŠ¥ã€‹çš„è¿™é¡¹è°ƒæŸ¥æ˜¯åœ¨æ­¤å‰ä¸€ç¯‡æ­éœ²å¤§å­¦ç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²å¿…ä¿®è¯¾ç¨‹åŒ®ä¹çš„æ–‡ç« ä¹‹åŽè¿›è¡Œçš„ã€‚å‚è§ã€Šçº½çº¦æ—¶æŠ¥ã€‹ï¼Œ1942å¹´6æœˆ21æ—¥ï¼Œç¬¬1é¡µã€‚ç¤¾è®ºè§1943å¹´4æœˆ4æ—¥ï¼Œç¬¬32é¡µã€‚å…³äºŽå¤§ä¼—åª’ä½“å¦‚ä½•æŠ¥é“è¿™é¡¹è°ƒæŸ¥ï¼Œå‚è§ç†æŸ¥å¾·Â·JÂ·å¸•å…‹æ–¯é¡¿ï¼Œã€Šå¯¹åŽ†å²çŸ¥ä¹‹ç”šå°‘â€”â€”ä»Žæ¥å¦‚æ­¤ã€‹ï¼Œã€ŠPhi Delta Kappanã€‹ 85å·ï¼Œç¬¬4æœŸï¼ˆ2003å¹´12æœˆï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬264-273é¡µã€‚

3 Benjamin Fine, â€œIgnorance of U.S. History Shown by College Freshmen,â€ New York Times, April 4, 1943, 1; Allan Nevins, â€œAmerican History for Americans,â€ New York Times Magazine, May 3, 1942, 6, 28. 14åœ¨äºŒåä¸–çºªå‰äºŒåå¹´ï¼ŒåŽ†å²åœ¨è¯¾ç¨‹ä¸­çš„åœ°ä½æ¯”ç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²ä¸Šä»»ä½•å…¶ä»–æ—¶æœŸéƒ½æ›´åŠ é‡è¦ã€‚ä¸€ä½æ•™è‚²å²å­¦å®¶å†™é“ï¼šâ€œåˆ°1900å¹´ï¼ŒåŽ†å²â€¦â€¦åœ¨å°å­¦å’Œä¸­å­¦æ‰€èŽ·å¾—çš„å…³æ³¨å’Œæ—¶é—´æ¯”æ‰€æœ‰å…¶ä»–ç¤¾ä¼šç ”ç©¶çš„æ€»å’Œè¿˜è¦å¤šã€‚â€åŽ†å²åœ¨1890å¹´è‡³1920å¹´å·¦å³å æ®ä¸»å¯¼åœ°ä½ï¼Œå°½ç®¡å…¶é¼Žç››æ—¶æœŸå¯èƒ½å‡ºçŽ°åœ¨1915å¹´ã€‚åŸƒå¾·åŠ Â·BÂ·éŸ¦æ–¯åˆ©ï¼Œã€Šå­¦æ ¡è¯¾ç¨‹ä¸­çš„åŽ†å²ã€‹ï¼Œã€Šå¯†è¥¿è¥¿æ¯”æ²³è°·åŽ†å²è¯„è®ºã€‹ 29ï¼ˆ1943å¹´3æœˆï¼‰ï¼š567ã€‚

14 History achieved a stronger position in the curriculum in the first two decades of the twentieth century than at any other time in American history. â€œBy 1900,â€ a historian of education wrote, â€œhistory . . . received more time and attention in both elementary and secondary schools than all the other social studies combined.â€ History dominated from about 1890â€“1920, although its apex probably came in 1915. Edgar B. Wesley, â€œHistory in the School Curriculum,â€ Mississippi Valley Historical Review 29 (March 1943): 567.

17 ED Hirschï¼Œå¼•è‡ª Chester E. 17 E. D. Hirsch, cited in Chester E. 18 Similar test results didnâ€™t show that what students know today is identical to what they knew in the past, but â€œthat each group performed about the same on the particular set of test questions designed for them to take. This observation is buttressed by the comparison of the distributions of item difficulty. The shape and location of these distributions for tests covering a span of 42 years are strikingly similar.â€ Dale Whittington, â€œWhat Have 17-Year-Olds Known in the Past?,â€ American Educational Research Journal 28 (Winter 1991): 759â€“80.

19 The origins of multiple-choice testing go back to the first mass-administered examination in American history, the Army Alpha and Beta, during World War I. See Daniel J. Kevles, â€œTesting the Armyâ€™s Intelligence: Psychologists and the Military in World War I,â€ Journal of American History 55 (December 1968): 565â€“81; Franz Samelson, â€œWorld War I Intelligence Testing and the Development of Psychology,â€ Journal of the History of the Behavioral Sciences 13 (July 1977): 274â€“82; and John Rury, â€œRace, Region, and Education: An Analysis of Black and White Scores on the 1917 Army Alpha Test,â€ Journal of Negro Education 57 (Winter 1988): 51â€“65. For critical and nontechnical overviews of modern testing, see Stephen Jay Gould, The Mismeasure of Man (New York: Norton, 1981); Banesh Hoffmann, The Tyranny of Testing (New York: Dover, 1962); Leon J. Kamin, The Science and Politics of IQ (Potomac, MD: Routledge, 1974); Paul L. Houts, ed., The Myth of Measurability (New York: Hart, 1977); and Cathy N. Davidson, Now You See It (New York: Penguin, 2011), esp. chap. 4. An evenhanded assessment from a major figure in modern psychometrics is Lee J. Cronbach, â€œFive Decades of Public Controversy over Mental Testing,â€ American Psychologist 30 (January 1975): 1â€“14.

22 Even professional historians do poorly when staring down items outside their research specializations. When historians trained at Berkeley, Harvard, and Stanford universities answered questions from a leading high school textbook, they scored a mere 35 percentâ€”in some cases lower than a comparison group of high school students taking Advanced Placement U.S. history courses. See Samuel S. Wineburg, â€œHistorical Problem Solving: A Study of the Cognitive Processes Used in the Evaluation of Documentary and Pictorial Evidence,â€ Journal of Educational Psychology 83, no. 1 (1991): 73â€“87.

28æœ‰å…³æ¦‚è¿°ï¼Œè¯·å‚é˜…å¼ æ™“æ˜Žè‘—ã€Šé¸­ç»¿æ±Ÿä¸Šçš„çº¢ç¿¼ï¼šä¸­å›½ã€è‹è”å’Œæœé²œç©ºæˆ˜ã€‹ï¼ˆå¤§å­¦åŸŽï¼šå¾·å…‹è¨æ–¯å†œå·¥å¤§å­¦å‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾ï¼Œ2003 å¹´ï¼‰ã€‚

29å¯¹äºŽéžé€‰æ‹©é¢˜ï¼Œå…¶åŠŸèƒ½ç­‰æ•ˆæŒ‡æ ‡æ˜¯é¢˜é¡¹-æµ‹è¯•ç›¸å…³æ€§ã€‚äºŒåˆ—ç›¸å…³æˆ–é¢˜é¡¹-æµ‹è¯•ç›¸å…³æ€§çš„èŒƒå›´ä¸º-1.00åˆ°+1.00ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­-1.00è¡¨ç¤ºå®Œå…¨æ— æ•ˆçš„æµ‹è¯•é¢˜ï¼Œ+1.00è¡¨ç¤ºå®Œç¾Žçš„æµ‹è¯•é¢˜ã€‚å¦‚æžœæœ€é«˜åˆ†ç»„çš„æ‰€æœ‰å­¦ç”Ÿéƒ½ç­”å¯¹äº†æŸä¸ªç‰¹å®šé¢˜ç›®ï¼Œè€Œæœ€ä½Žåˆ†ç»„çš„æ‰€æœ‰å­¦ç”Ÿéƒ½ç­”é”™äº†ï¼Œåˆ™ç›¸å…³æ€§ä¸º+1.00ï¼ˆåä¹‹äº¦ç„¶ï¼Œå³å®Œå…¨è´Ÿç›¸å…³ï¼‰ã€‚å¤§å¤šæ•°å¤§åž‹æµ‹è¯•ä¸­çš„é€‰æ‹©é¢˜çš„äºŒåˆ—ç›¸å…³ç³»æ•°åœ¨+0.25åˆ°+0.50ä¹‹é—´ã€‚

29 For non-multiple-choice items, the functional equivalent is the item-test correlation. Biserial or item-test correlations range from âˆ’1.00 to +1.00, with âˆ’1.00 being a score for a completely ineffective test item and +1.00 one for a perfect item. A +1.00 correlation would be achieved if all students in the highest scoring group got a particular item correct and all students in the lower scoring group got it incorrect (conversely, for a perfect negative correlation). Most multiple-choice items on large-scale tests have biserial correlations that range from +.25 to +.50.

30å…³äºŽå¤§è§„æ¨¡æˆå°±æµ‹è¯•ä¸­çš„åè§ï¼Œå‚è§ Roy O. Freedleï¼Œâ€œçº æ­£ SAT çš„ç§æ—å’Œç¤¾ä¼šé˜¶å±‚åè§ï¼šä¸€ç§é‡æ–°ä¼°è®¡ SAT åˆ†æ•°çš„æ–¹æ³•â€ï¼Œã€Šå“ˆä½›æ•™è‚²è¯„è®ºã€‹ 73ï¼ˆ2003 å¹´æ˜¥å­£ï¼‰ï¼š1-43ã€‚å…³äºŽ Freedle è®ºç‚¹çš„éžæŠ€æœ¯æ€§æ¦‚è¿°ï¼Œå‚è§ Jeffrey R. Youngï¼Œâ€œç ”ç©¶äººå‘˜æŒ‡æŽ§ SAT å­˜åœ¨ç§æ—åè§â€ï¼Œã€Šé«˜ç­‰æ•™è‚²çºªäº‹æŠ¥ã€‹ï¼Œ2003 å¹´ 10 æœˆ 10 æ—¥ï¼ŒA34ï¼›ä»¥åŠ Jay Mathewsï¼Œâ€œåè§é—®é¢˜â€ï¼Œã€Šå¤§è¥¿æ´‹æœˆåˆŠã€‹ 292ï¼ˆ2003 å¹´ 11 æœˆï¼‰ï¼š130-40ã€‚

30 For bias in large-scale achievement testing, see Roy O. Freedle, â€œCorrecting the SATâ€™s Ethnic and Social-Class Bias: A Method for Reestimating SAT Scores,â€ Harvard Educational Review 73 (Spring 2003): 1â€“43. For nontechnical overviews of Freedleâ€™s argument, see Jeffrey R. Young, â€œResearchers Charge Racial Bias on the SAT,â€ Chronicle of Higher Education, October 10, 2003, A34; and Jay Mathews, â€œThe Bias Question,â€ Atlantic Monthly 292 (November 2003): 130â€“40.

31å®Œç¾Žçš„æ­£æ€æ›²çº¿åœ¨è‡ªç„¶ç•Œä¸­æžå…¶ç½•è§ï¼Œé€šå¸¸æ˜¯æ¦‚çŽ‡å®žéªŒçš„ç»“æžœï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚æŠ›æŽ·ä¸€åƒæžš25ç¾Žåˆ†ç¡¬å¸ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡è®°å½•æ­£é¢æœä¸Šçš„æ¬¡æ•°ï¼›éšç€æŠ›æŽ·æ¬¡æ•°è¶‹äºŽæ— ç©·å¤§ï¼Œæ›²çº¿å˜å¾—è¶Šæ¥è¶Šå¯¹ç§°ã€‚åªæœ‰é¢„å…ˆè®¾å®šç»“æžœï¼Œæ‰èƒ½ä½¿åƒåŽ†å²èƒ½åŠ›è¿™æ ·åˆ†æ•£çš„äº‹ç‰©å‘ˆçŽ°å‡ºå¦‚æ­¤è§„æ•´çš„æ¨¡å¼ã€‚å¯¹æ­£æ€æ›²çº¿çš„æœ€ä½³æ‰¹åˆ¤æ¥è‡ªä¸€ä½ç‰©ç†å­¦å®¶ï¼šå‚è§è²åˆ©æ™®Â·èŽ«é‡Œæ£®ï¼ˆPhilip Morrisonï¼‰çš„ã€Šé’Ÿå½¢é™·é˜±ã€‹ï¼ˆâ€œThe Bell Shaped Pitfallâ€ï¼‰ï¼Œè½½äºŽéœèŒ¨ï¼ˆHoutsï¼‰ä¸»ç¼–çš„ã€Šå¯æµ‹é‡æ€§çš„ç¥žè¯ã€‹ï¼ˆMyth of Measurabilityï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬82-89é¡µã€‚å¦è§æ¬§æ–‡Â·MÂ·å…‹æ´›èŒ¨ï¼ˆIrving M. Klotzï¼‰çš„ã€Šå…³äºŽé’Ÿå½¢æ›²çº¿ã€ç—›é£Žå’Œå¤©æ‰ã€‹ï¼ˆâ€œOf Bell Curves, Gout, and Geniusâ€ï¼‰ï¼Œã€ŠPhi Delta Kappanã€‹ 77å·4æœŸï¼ˆ1995å¹´12æœˆï¼‰ï¼šç¬¬279-280é¡µã€‚

31 Perfect normal curves are extremely rare in nature and typically result from experiments in probability, such as tossing a thousand quarters in the air, each time plotting the number of heads; as the number of tosses approaches infinity, the curve becomes more and more symmetrical. Only by fixing the results beforehand can one make something as diffuse as historical ability fall into such well-shaped patterns. The best critique of the normal curve is by a physicist: see Philip Morrison, â€œThe Bell Shaped Pitfall,â€ in Myth of Measurability, ed. Houts, 82â€“89. See also Irving M. Klotz, â€œOf Bell Curves, Gout, and Genius,â€ Phi Delta Kappan 77, no. 4 (December 1995): 279â€“80.

32 Whittingtonï¼Œâ€œ17å²é’å°‘å¹´è¿‡åŽ»çŸ¥é“ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Ÿâ€ï¼Œ778ã€‚äºŒåˆ—è”è¡¨ï¼ˆåŠå…¶ç­‰æ•ˆå½¢å¼ï¼ŒçŽ°ç”¨äºŽé¡¹ç›®ååº”ç†è®ºæ–¹æ³•ï¼‰çš„ä½¿ç”¨åŸºäºŽæ‰€æµ‹è¯•â€œæž„å¿µâ€çš„å•ç»´æ€§ã€‚ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´ï¼Œâ€œåŽ†å²çŸ¥è¯†â€è¢«è§†ä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªå•ä¸€å®žä½“ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯åƒJ. Carleton Bellåœ¨1917å¹´æå‡ºçš„ç†è®ºé‚£æ ·ï¼Œç”±ä¸åŒå› ç´ å’Œå½±å“æž„æˆçš„æ¨¡ç³Šæž„å¿µã€‚å¿ƒç†æµ‹é‡å­¦æŽ¨ç†çš„å…¸åž‹ä¾‹å­å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼šâ€œä¸Žæ€»åˆ†ç›¸å…³ç³»æ•°ä½ŽäºŽ0.15çš„é¢˜ç›®å¯èƒ½éœ€è¦é‡æ–°è®¾è®¡ã€‚æœ€å¥½çš„çŒœæµ‹æ˜¯ï¼Œè¿™äº›é¢˜ç›®è¡¡é‡çš„æŠ€èƒ½æˆ–èƒ½åŠ›ä¸Žæ•´ä¸ªæµ‹è¯•è¡¡é‡çš„æŠ€èƒ½æˆ–èƒ½åŠ›ä¸åŒâ€¦â€¦ä¸€èˆ¬æ¥è¯´ï¼Œé¢˜ç›®è¶ŠåŒè´¨ï¼Œæµ‹è¯•å°±è¶Šå¥½ï¼ˆå³è¶Šå¯é ï¼‰ã€‚â€ Jerard Kehoeï¼Œâ€œå¤šé¡¹é€‰æ‹©é¢˜çš„åŸºæœ¬é¡¹ç›®åˆ†æžâ€ï¼Œã€Šå®žç”¨è¯„ä¼°ã€ç ”ç©¶ä¸Žè¯„ä»·ã€‹ 4ï¼Œç¬¬1æœŸï¼Œ1995å¹´ï¼Œç¬¬1-10é¡µã€‚ 10ï¼ˆ1995 å¹´ 11 æœˆï¼‰ï¼Œhttp://pareonline.net/getvn.asp?v =4&n= 10ã€‚

32 Whittington, â€œWhat Have 17-Year-Olds Known in the Past?,â€ 778. The use of biserials (and their equivalents, now employed with Item Response Theory methods) is predicated on the unidimensionality of the â€œconstructâ€ being tested. That is, â€œhistorical knowledgeâ€ is considered a single entity, not a woolly construct composed of different factors and influences in the spirit of J. Carleton Bellâ€™s 1917 formulation. Typical of psychometric reasoning is the following statement: â€œItems that correlate less than .15 with the total test score should probably be restructured. Oneâ€™s best guess is that such items do not measure the same skill or ability as does the test on the whole. . . . Generally, a test is better (i.e., more reliable) the more homogeneous the items.â€ Jerard Kehoe, â€œBasic Item Analysis for Multiple-Choice Tests,â€ Practical Assessment, Research & Evaluation 4, no. 10 (November 1995), http://pareonline.net/getvn.asp?v=4&n=10.

33æ­£å¦‚åˆä½œæµ‹è¯•æœåŠ¡æœºæž„åœ¨ 1936 å¹´å‘æ•™å¸ˆè§£é‡Šçš„é‚£æ ·ï¼Œâ€œæµ‹è¯•çš„ç›®çš„æ˜¯å‘çŽ°ä¸ªä½“ä¹‹é—´çš„å·®å¼‚ï¼Œè¿™ä¹Ÿå¿…é¡»æ˜¯æµ‹è¯•ä¸­æ¯ä¸ªé¢˜ç›®çš„ç›®çš„ã€‚æ‰€æœ‰å­¦ç”Ÿéƒ½èƒ½å›žç­”çš„é¢˜ç›®æ˜¾ç„¶æ— åŠ©äºŽå‘çŽ°è¿™äº›å·®å¼‚ï¼Œå› æ­¤æµ‹è¯•ä¸­åº”è¯¥å¾ˆå°‘åŒ…å«è¿™ç±»é¢˜ç›®ã€‚â€ åˆä½œæµ‹è¯•æœåŠ¡æœºæž„ï¼Œã€Šåˆä½œæˆå°±æµ‹è¯•ã€‹ï¼Œç¬¬ 6 é¡µã€‚

33 As the Cooperative Test Service explained to teachers in 1936, â€œThe purpose of the test is to discover differences between individuals, and this must also be the purpose of each item in the test. Items that all students can answer will obviously not help to discover such differences and therefore the test should contain very few such items.â€ Cooperative Test Service, Cooperative Achievement Tests, 6.

ç¬¬äºŒç« 

CHAPTER TWO

1 147 Cong. Rec. 27 Full disclosure: I wrote to him in my capacity as executive co-director of the National History Education Clearinghouse, an initiative of the Department of Education, whose charge was to gather â€œbest practicesâ€ from TAH projects around the country and feature them on a website dedicated to improving history education. The National Clearinghouse was a collaboration of George Mason Universityâ€™s Center for History and New Media, directed by the late Roy Rosenzweig, The Stanford History Education Group, and the American Historical Association. The National Clearinghouse website lives on under the auspices of the Roy Rosenzweig Center for History and New Media, teachinghistory.org.

19æ´¥æ©ï¼ˆZinnï¼‰å°†å¾·ç´¯æ–¯é¡¿çš„æ­»äº¡äººæ•°åˆ—ä¸ºâ€œè¶…è¿‡10ä¸‡äººâ€ï¼ˆ421ï¼‰ï¼Œå¹¶å¼•ç”¨äº†æˆ´ç»´Â·æ¬§æ–‡ï¼ˆDavid Irvingï¼‰1963å¹´å‡ºç‰ˆçš„ã€Šå¾·ç´¯æ–¯é¡¿çš„æ¯ç­ã€‹ï¼ˆThe Destruction of Dresden ï¼‰ä¸€ä¹¦ã€‚éšç€æ—¶é—´çš„æŽ¨ç§»ï¼Œæ¬§æ–‡çš„æ„å›¾è¶Šæ¥è¶Šæ¸…æ™°ï¼šä»–è½»ä¿¡ï¼ˆæˆ–è“„æ„ï¼‰åœ°å¼•ç”¨äº†çº³ç²¹æä¾›çš„æ­»äº¡äººæ•°æ•°æ®ï¼Œç”¨äºŽå®£ä¼ ç›®çš„ã€‚æœ€è¿‘ï¼Œç”±æ³¢èŒ¨å¦å¾·å›½è”é‚¦å›½é˜²å†›å†›äº‹åŽ†å²ç ”ç©¶æ‰€ç§‘å­¦ä¸»ä»»ç½—å°”å¤«-è¿ªç‰¹Â·ç©†å‹’ï¼ˆRolf-Dieter MÃ¼llerï¼‰é¢†å¯¼çš„ä¸€ä¸ªç”±13ä½å¾·å›½è‘—ååŽ†å²å­¦å®¶ç»„æˆçš„å§”å‘˜ä¼šï¼Œå¯¹å¾·ç´¯æ–¯é¡¿çš„å‡ºç”Ÿè®°å½•è¿›è¡Œäº†è¯¦å°½çš„å®¡æŸ¥ï¼Œå¹¶å°†å…¶ä¸Žè½°ç‚¸ä¸­éš¾æ°‘çš„åå•è¿›è¡Œäº†æ¯”è¾ƒã€‚å§”å‘˜ä¼šç¡®è®¤äº†18,000åç©ºè¢­å—å®³è€…ï¼Œå¹¶è¡¨ç¤ºâ€œæœ€å¤šå¯èƒ½æœ‰25,000äººâ€ï¼Œè¿™å½»åº•é©³æ–¥äº†çº³ç²¹åŒæƒ…è€…é•¿æœŸä»¥æ¥æ‰€å®£æ‰¬çš„è¯´æ³•ï¼Œå³ç›Ÿå†›å¯¹å¾·ç´¯æ–¯é¡¿çš„è½°ç‚¸ç­‰åŒäºŽçº³ç²¹åœ¨å¥¥æ–¯ç»´è¾›é›†ä¸­è¥çš„æš´è¡Œã€‚ç½—å°”å¤«-è¿ªç‰¹Â·ç©†å‹’ï¼Œå¼•è‡ªåšæ‰¬Â·æ½˜åˆ‡å¤«æ–¯åŸºï¼Œã€Šå¾·ç´¯æ–¯é¡¿è½°ç‚¸æ­»äº¡äººæ•°ä½ŽäºŽé¢„æœŸã€‹ï¼Œã€Šæ¯æ—¥ç”µè®¯æŠ¥ã€‹ï¼ˆä¼¦æ•¦ï¼‰ï¼Œ2008å¹´10æœˆ2æ—¥ã€‚å¦è§ç½—å°”å¤«-è¿ªç‰¹Â·ç©†å‹’ã€å¦®å¯Â·èˆæ©èµ«å°”å’Œæ‰˜é©¬æ–¯Â·ç»´å¾·æ‹‰ç¼–ï¼Œ ã€Šå¾·ç´¯æ–¯é¡¿çš„æ¯ç­ã€‹ï¼ˆå¾·å›½ï¼šV&R Unipresså‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾ï¼Œ2010å¹´ï¼‰ã€‚å…³äºŽå¤§å«Â·æ¬§æ–‡çš„è°Žè¨€ï¼Œè¯·å‚é˜…ç†æŸ¥å¾·Â·JÂ·åŸƒæ–‡æ–¯æ‰€è‘—çš„ã€Šå…³äºŽå¸Œç‰¹å‹’çš„è°Žè¨€ï¼šåŽ†å²ã€å¤§å± æ€å’Œå¤§å«Â·æ¬§æ–‡å®¡åˆ¤ã€‹ï¼ˆçº½çº¦ï¼šåŸºç¡€ä¹¦ç±å‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾ï¼Œ2002 å¹´ï¼‰ã€‚

19 Zinn lists the number of deaths at Dresden as â€œmore than 100,000â€ (421), citing David Irvingâ€™s 1963 book The Destruction of Dresden. With an intent that has become easier to discern with time, Irving credulously (or calculatingly) drew on mortality figures provided by the Nazis for propagandistic purposes. More recently, a commission of thirteen prominent German historians led by Rolf-Dieter MÃ¼ller, scientific director of the German Armed Forces Military History Research Institute in Potsdam, conducted an exhaustive examination of the cityâ€™s birth records, comparing them to lists of refugees from the firebombing. The commission identified 18,000 victims of the raids, with â€œa maximum of 25,000,â€ once and for all debunking the claims long favored by Nazi sympathizers, who held up the Alliesâ€™ bombing of Dresden as tantamount to Nazi atrocities at Auschwitz. Rolf-Dieter MÃ¼ller, cited in Bojan Pancevski, â€œDresden Bombing Death Toll Lower than Thought,â€ Telegraph (London), October, 2, 2008. See also Rolf-Dieter MÃ¼ller, Nicole SchÃ¶nherr, and Thomas Widera, eds., Die ZerstÃ¶rung Dresden [The destruction of Dresden] (Germany: V&R Unipress, 2010). On David Irvingâ€™s mendacity, see Richard J. Evans, Lying about Hitler: History, Holocaust, and the David Irving Trial (New York: Basic Books, 2002).

20 Alan J. Levine, The Strategic Bombing of Germany, 1940â€“1945 (Westport, CT: Praeger, 1992).

29 Herbert P. Bixï¼Œâ€œæ—¥æœ¬å»¶è¿ŸæŠ•é™ï¼šé‡æ–°è§£è¯»â€ï¼Œã€Šå¤–äº¤å²ã€‹ 19ï¼Œç¬¬ 2 æœŸï¼ˆ1995 å¹´æ˜¥å­£ï¼‰ï¼š214ã€‚

30ç¾Žå›½å¯¹å¤–å…³ç³»å¤–äº¤æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œç¾Žå›½å›½åŠ¡é™¢ï¼Œç¬¬876é¡µï¼Œhttp://images.library.wisc.edu/FRUS/EFacs/1945Berlinv01/reference/frus.frus1945berlinv01.i0023.pdfã€‚æ—©åœ¨1940å¹´ï¼Œç¾Žå›½å¯†ç ç ´è¯‘äººå‘˜å°±èƒ½å¤ŸæˆªèŽ·å¹¶ç ´è¯‘æ—¥æœ¬çš„ç”µæŠ¥ã€‚è¿™ä»½ç”µæŠ¥æœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªè¯‘æœ¬ï¼Œä½†éƒ½æ²¡æœ‰åŒ…å«æ´¥æ©å¼•ç”¨çš„é‚£å¥è¯ã€‚MAGICç³»ç»Ÿåœ¨ç´§æ€¥æƒ…å†µä¸‹å®Œæˆçš„è¯‘æœ¬é™„æœ‰è¯‘è€…å’Œæ”¿ç­–åˆ†æžå‘˜çš„è¯„è®ºï¼Œå¹¶æä¾›ç»™ç™½å®«å’Œå…³é”®å†³ç­–è€…ã€‚æˆ˜åŽï¼Œå¦ä¸€ä¸ªè¯‘æœ¬åˆ™ä½¿ç”¨äº†ç¼´èŽ·çš„æ—¥æœ¬å¤–åŠ¡çœæ¡£æ¡ˆå‰¯æœ¬ï¼Œè€ŒéžæˆªèŽ·çš„ç”µæŠ¥ã€‚æ­¤å¤„å‘ˆçŽ°çš„è¯‘æœ¬æ˜¯åŽè€…ï¼Œç”±ç¾Žå›½å›½åŠ¡é™¢å‡†å¤‡å‡ºç‰ˆã€‚çº¦ä¹¦äºšÂ·åšèŒ¨åšå£«ï¼ˆJoshua Botts, PhDï¼‰ï¼Œç¾Žå›½å›½åŠ¡é™¢åŽ†å²å­¦å®¶åŠžå…¬å®¤ï¼Œ2015å¹´8æœˆ21æ—¥è‡´ä½œè€…çš„ç§äººä¿¡ä»¶ã€‚å³ä½¿åœ¨2000å¹´8æœˆçš„åŽæœŸè‘—ä½œä¸­ï¼Œæ´¥æ©ä»ç„¶åšæŒè®¤ä¸ºâ€”â€”å°½ç®¡æ‰€æœ‰è¯æ®éƒ½ä¸Žä¹‹ç›¸åâ€”â€”â€œå¦‚æžœä¸€ä¸ªæ¡ä»¶èƒ½å¤Ÿå¾—åˆ°æ»¡è¶³ï¼Œæ—¥æœ¬äººå°±å‡†å¤‡æŠ•é™â€”â€”é‚£å°±æ˜¯ä¿ç•™å¤©çš‡ã€‚â€å‚è§howardzinn.org/downfall/ã€‚

30 Foreign Relations of the United States Diplomatic Papers, Department of State, p. 876, http://images.library.wisc.edu/FRUS/EFacs/1945Berlinv01/reference/frus.frus1945berlinv01.i0023.pdf. As early as 1940, American code-breakers were able to intercept and decode Japanese transmissions. Two translations of this cable exist, neither of which contains the sentence Zinn quotes. MAGIC translations made in the heat of the moment were accompanied by commentary by translators and policy analysts, and made available to the White House and key policy makers. A later translation, after the war, was done using copies of captured Japanese Foreign Office records rather than the intercepts. The translation appearing here was the latter, prepared for publication by the Department of State. Personal correspondence, Joshua Botts, PhD, Office of the Historian, U.S. Department of State, to author, August 21, 2015. Even in his later writing, in August 2000 Zinn continued to insistâ€”despite all evidence to the contraryâ€”that â€œthe Japanese were ready for surrender, if one condition could be metâ€”the retention of the Emperor.â€ See howardzinn.org/downfall/.

62 Sam Roberts, â€œPodcast: Rosenberg Case Open and Shut?â€ City Room (blog), New York Times, September 18, 2009, http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/09/18/podcast-rosenberg-case-open-and-shut/. Zinnâ€™s nonchalance toward new scholarship seems to have characterized his talks to teachers as well. The chief historian of the JFK Library, Sheldon Stern, invited Zinn to speak several times at the summer institutes for local teachers, where Zinn was â€œalways a big hit.â€ Stern, however, recalls being struck by the fact that Zinn â€œinvariably placed a folder of handwritten, yellowed, dog-eared, and clearly decades-old notes on the podium before he spoke. Not surprisingly, he never referred to recent studies, interpretations, or evidence.â€ Sheldon M. Stern, â€œHoward Zinn Briefly Recalled,â€ History News Network, February 9, 2010, http://hnn.us/articles/122924.html.

ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œçº½çº¦å·žç«‹å¤§å­¦ç§‘ç‰¹å…°åˆ†æ ¡çš„ EDU 514â€œå°å­¦ç¤¾ä¼šç ”ç©¶æ•™å­¦â€ï¼›å®¾å¤•æ³•å°¼äºšå·žç«‹å¤§å­¦é˜¿å°”å›¾çº³åˆ†æ ¡çš„ SS ED 430Wâ€œå°å­¦ç¤¾ä¼šç ”ç©¶æ•™å­¦â€ï¼›å°ç¬¬å®‰çº³å¤§å­¦-æ™®æ¸¡å¤§å­¦å°ç¬¬å®‰çº³æ³¢åˆ©æ–¯åˆ†æ ¡çš„ EDUC M442â€œä¸­å­¦ç¤¾ä¼šç ”ç©¶æ•™å­¦â€ï¼›ä»¥åŠè¥¿æ–¹å­¦é™¢çš„ Education 342/542â€œé«˜ä¸­è‹±è¯­å’Œç¤¾ä¼šç ”ç©¶æ•™å­¦æ‰¹åˆ¤æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆç¤¾ä¼šç ”ç©¶ä¸“ä¸šæ–¹å‘ï¼‰â€ã€‚è¿™äº›ä¾‹å­åœ¨æœ¬æ–‡æ—©æœŸç‰ˆæœ¬å‘è¡¨æ—¶ä»ç„¶æœ‰æ•ˆï¼šSam Wineburgï¼Œâ€œè¿‡åº¦ç¡®å®šæ€§ï¼šéœåŽå¾·Â·æ´¥æ©çš„ã€Šç¾Žå›½äººæ°‘çš„åŽ†å²ã€‹çš„ä¸è¶³ä¹‹å¤„â€ï¼Œã€Šç¾Žå›½æ•™è‚²å®¶ã€‹ï¼Œ2012-13 å¹´å†¬å­£åˆŠï¼Œhttps://www.aft.org/sites/default/files/periodicals/Wineburg.pdfã€‚

ç¬¬å››ç« 

CHAPTER FOUR

1æœ¬ç« æœ€åˆæ˜¯2009å¹´1æœˆåº”é‚€åœ¨ç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²å­¦ä¼šå‘è¡¨çš„æ¼”è®²ã€‚éƒ¨åˆ†å†…å®¹æ‘˜è‡ªSam Wineburgå’ŒJack Schneideråˆè‘—çš„ã€Šå¸ƒé²å§†åˆ†ç±»æ³•æ˜¯å¦æŒ‡å‘é”™è¯¯çš„æ–¹å‘ï¼Ÿã€‹ï¼ˆâ€œWas Bloom's Taxonomy Pointed in the Wrong Direction?â€ï¼‰ï¼Œè¯¥æ–‡å‘è¡¨äºŽã€ŠPhi Delta Kappanã€‹ç¬¬91å·ç¬¬4æœŸï¼ˆ2009å¹´12æœˆï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬56-61é¡µã€‚æˆ‘ä»Žä¸Žåˆè‘—è€…Schneiderçš„è®¨è®ºä¸­èŽ·ç›ŠåŒªæµ…ï¼Œä¹Ÿä»Žä»–æ‰€è‘—çš„ã€Šä»Žè±¡ç‰™å¡”åˆ°å­¦æ ¡ï¼šå­¦æœ¯ç ”ç©¶å¦‚ä½•æˆä¸ºæ•™è‚²ä¸­çš„å¸¸è¯†ã€‹ï¼ˆé©¬è¨è¯¸å¡žå·žå‰‘æ¡¥ï¼šå“ˆä½›æ•™è‚²å‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾ï¼Œ2014å¹´ï¼‰ä¸€ä¹¦ä¸­å…³äºŽå¸ƒé²å§†çš„ç« èŠ‚ä¸­èŽ·ç›Šè‰¯å¤šã€‚

1 This chapter began as an invited lecture to the American Historical Association in January 2009. Portions are drawn from Sam Wineburg and Jack Schneider, â€œWas Bloomâ€™s Taxonomy Pointed in the Wrong Direction?â€ Phi Delta Kappan 91, no. 4 (December 2009): 56â€“61. I benefited immeasurably from discussions with coauthor Schneider, as well from his chapter on Bloom in his book From the Ivory Tower to the Schoolhouse: How Scholarship Becomes Common Knowledge in Education (Cambridge, MA: Harvard Education Press, 2014).

2æ–½è€å¾·ï¼Œã€Šè±¡ç‰™å¡”ã€‹ï¼Œ44ã€‚

2 Schneider, From the Ivory Tower, 44.

3 David R. Krathwohlã€Benjamin S. Bloom å’Œ Bertram B. Masiaï¼Œã€Šæ•™è‚²ç›®æ ‡åˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ‰‹å†Œ IIï¼šæƒ…æ„Ÿé¢†åŸŸã€‹ï¼ˆçº½çº¦ï¼šDavid McKayï¼Œ1964 å¹´ï¼‰ã€‚

3 David R. Krathwohl, Benjamin S. Bloom, and Bertram B. Masia, The Taxonomy of Educational Objectives: Handbook II: The Affective Domain (New York: David McKay, 1964).

4æœ‰å…³è¿™ç§æ€ç»´æ–¹å¼çš„ä¸€ä¸ªä¾‹å­ï¼Œè¯·å‚é˜… Robert R. Newtonï¼Œâ€œé«˜ä¸­è¯¾ç¨‹ï¼šå¯»æ±‚ç»Ÿä¸€æ€§å’Œè¿žè´¯æ€§â€ï¼Œã€Šé«˜ä¸­æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 62 (1979)ï¼š289ã€‚

4 For an example of this kind of thinking, see Robert R. Newton, â€œThe High School Curriculum: Search for Unity and Coherence,â€ High School Journal 62 (1979): 289.

5å…³äºŽæˆ‘æ—©æœŸç ”ç©¶çš„ä¸€ä¸ªä¾‹å­ï¼Œè¯·å‚é˜… Samuel S. Wineburg çš„æ–‡ç« â€œè®ºåŽ†å²æ–‡æœ¬çš„é˜…è¯»ï¼šå…³äºŽå­¦æ ¡ä¸Žå­¦é™¢ä¹‹é—´é¸¿æ²Ÿçš„ç¬”è®°â€ï¼Œè½½äºŽã€Šç¾Žå›½æ•™è‚²ç ”ç©¶æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 28 (1991)ï¼Œç¬¬ 495-519 é¡µï¼›å…³äºŽæˆ‘æœ€è¿‘çš„æ€è€ƒï¼Œè¯·å‚é˜…æˆ‘çš„æ–‡ç« â€œä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆåŽ†å²æ€ç»´ä¸ŽåŽ†å²æ— å…³â€ï¼Œè½½äºŽã€ŠåŽ†å²æ–°é—»ï¼šå·žå’Œåœ°æ–¹åŽ†å²åä¼šæ‚å¿—ã€‹ 71ï¼Œç¬¬ 2 æœŸ (2016)ï¼Œç¬¬ 13-16 é¡µã€‚

5 For an example of one of my earliest investigations, see Samuel S. 6 Sam Wineburg ç­‰äººï¼Œâ€œå…±åŒä¿¡ä»°ä¸Žæ–‡åŒ–è¯¾ç¨‹ï¼šåŽ†å²æ„è¯†çš„ä»£é™…ç ”ç©¶â€ï¼Œã€Šç¾Žå›½æ•™è‚²ç ”ç©¶æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 44ï¼ˆ2007ï¼‰ï¼š40-76ã€‚

6 Sam Wineburg et al., â€œCommon Belief and the Cultural Curriculum: An Intergeneration Study of Historical Consciousness,â€ American Education Research Journal 44 (2007): 40â€“76.

7æœ¬ç« ä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰ä¸“æœ‰åè¯å‡ä¸ºç¬”åã€‚

7 All proper names in this chapter are pseudonyms.

8 çº½çº¦æ—¶æŠ¥ï¼Œ1892 å¹´ 7 æœˆ 22 æ—¥ï¼Œç¬¬ 8 é¡µï¼Œhttp://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/07/22/106809661.html ?pageNumber =8ã€‚

8 New York Times, July 22, 1892, 8, http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/07/22/106809661.html?pageNumber=8.

9 Sam Wineburgï¼Œâ€œæœ€ç»ˆæŠ¥å‘Šï¼šå¨æ–¯åº·æ˜Ÿå¤§å­¦æ‹‰å…‹ç½—æ–¯åˆ†æ ¡ç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²æ•™å­¦èµ„åŠ©è®¡åˆ’è¯„ä¼°â€ï¼Œ2008 å¹´ 10 æœˆ 16 æ—¥ã€‚åŽç››é¡¿ç‰¹åŒºï¼šç¾Žå›½æ•™è‚²éƒ¨ã€‚

10 Thomas J. Schlerethï¼Œâ€œå“¥ä¼¦æ¯”äºšã€å“¥ä¼¦å¸ƒå’Œå“¥ä¼¦å¸ƒä¸»ä¹‰â€ï¼Œã€Šç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²æ‚å¿—ã€‹79ï¼ˆ1992 å¹´ 12 æœˆï¼‰ï¼š937-68ã€‚

ç¬¬äº”ç« 

CHAPTER FIVE

1å…³äºŽæ„Ÿæ©èŠ‚è±¡å¾æ„ä¹‰çš„å˜åŒ–ï¼Œè¯·å‚é˜… Janet Siskindï¼Œâ€œæ„Ÿæ©èŠ‚çš„å‘æ˜Žï¼šç¾Žå›½æ°‘æ—æ€§çš„ä»ªå¼â€ï¼Œã€Šäººç±»å­¦è¯„è®ºã€‹ 12 (1992): 167â€“91ã€‚

1 On the changing symbolism of Thanksgiving, see Janet Siskind, â€œThe Invention of Thanksgiving: A Ritual of American Nationality,â€ Critique of Anthropology 12 (1992): 167â€“91.

å¦‚ä»Šï¼Œç¾Žå›½äººè®°ä½æ„Ÿæ©èŠ‚çš„æ–¹å¼æ˜¯æŒ‰æœˆä»½å’Œæ—¥æœŸï¼Œå³æœ€åŽä¸€ä¸ªæ˜ŸæœŸå››ã€‚äººä»¬é€šå¸¸åœ¨11æœˆåº†ç¥ï¼Œå¹¶å¿˜è®°äº†å®ƒæœ€åˆçš„æ—¥æœŸã€‚ä½†å¯¹äºŽ1789å¹´çš„çº½çº¦äººæ¥è¯´ï¼Œæƒ…å†µåˆ™æˆªç„¶ä¸åŒã€‚ä»–ä»¬å°†11æœˆ26æ—¥è§†ä¸ºâ€œæ’¤ç¦»æ—¥â€çš„ç¬¬äºŒå¤©ï¼Œ1783å¹´ï¼Œæœ€åŽä¸€æ‰¹è‹±å›½å†›é˜Ÿæ’¤ç¦»äº†çº½çº¦ã€‚å¯¹äºŽæ—©æœŸå…±å’Œå›½çš„å…¬æ°‘æ¥è¯´ï¼Œ11æœˆ26æ—¥æ˜¯ç¾Žå›½ç‹¬ç«‹åŽçš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå®Œæ•´çºªå¿µæ—¥ï¼Œæ ‡å¿—ç€ç¾Žå›½é¢†åœŸæ‘†è„±äº†è‹±å›½å†›é˜Ÿçš„ç»Ÿæ²»ã€‚åˆ°äº†1863å¹´æž—è‚¯æ€»ç»Ÿå‘å¸ƒæ„Ÿæ©èŠ‚å…¬å‘Šæ—¶ï¼Œä»¥åŠ1942å¹´ç½—æ–¯ç¦æ€»ç»Ÿå°†å…¶åˆæ³•åŒ–æ—¶ï¼Œäººä»¬æ—©å·²æ·¡å¿˜äº†â€œæ’¤ç¦»æ—¥â€ä¸Žè¿™ä¸€å¤©çš„è”ç³»ã€‚ä½†ä¸Ž11æœˆä¸‹æ—¬ï¼Œå°¤å…¶æ˜¯æ˜ŸæœŸå››çš„è”ç³»å´æ ¹æ·±è’‚å›ºã€‚å…‹åˆ©å¤«é¡¿Â·èƒ¡å¾·ï¼Œã€Šä¸€æ®µæ— æ³•åˆ©ç”¨çš„è¿‡åŽ»ï¼šåŸŽå¸‚ç²¾è‹±ã€çº½çº¦å¸‚çš„â€œæ’¤ç¦»æ—¥â€ä¸Žè®°å¿†æ–‡åŒ–çš„è½¬å˜ã€‹ï¼Œã€Šç¤¾ä¼šå²æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 37ï¼ˆ2004ï¼‰ï¼š883-913ã€‚

2 Americans today remember Thanksgiving by its month and day, the last Thursday in November, and forget its original date. But it would have been different for New Yorkers in 1789, who recognized November 26 as the day after â€œEvacuation Day,â€ when in 1783 the last British troops quit New York. For citizens of the early republic, November 26 was the anniversary of the first full day of nationhood, freed of British troops on American soil. By the time that President Lincoln issued his Thanksgiving Proclamation in 1863, and certainly by the time President Roosevelt made it legal in 1942, the association with Evacuation Day had faded from popular memory. But the association with late November, and particularly with Thursday, stubbornly remained. Clifton Hood, â€œAn Unusable Past: Urban Elites, New York Cityâ€™s Evacuation Day, and the Transformation of Memory Culture,â€ Journal of Social History 37 (2004): 883â€“913.

3 â€œ1799 å¹´æ„Ÿæ©èŠ‚å…¬å‘Šâ€ï¼Œä¹”æ²»Â·åŽç››é¡¿çš„å¼—å†œå±±åº„ï¼Œmountvernon.orgï¼Œhttp://www.mountvernon.org/education/primary-sources-2/article/thanksgiving-proclamation-of-1789/ã€‚

3 â€œThanksgiving Proclamation of 1799,â€ George Washingtonâ€™s Mount Vernon, mountvernon.org, http://www.mountvernon.org/education/primary-sources-2/article/thanksgiving-proclamation-of-1789/.

4 LaHayeï¼Œå¼•è‡ª Peter R. Henriquesï¼Œã€ŠçŽ°å®žçš„æ¢¦æƒ³å®¶ï¼šä¹”æ²»Â·åŽç››é¡¿è‚–åƒã€‹ï¼ˆå¤æ´›èŒ¨ç»´å°”ï¼šå¼—å‰å°¼äºšå¤§å­¦ï¼Œ2006 å¹´ï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬ 168 é¡µã€‚

4 LaHaye, cited in Peter R. Henriques, Realistic Visionary: A Portrait of George Washington (Charlottesville: University of Virginia, 2006), 168.

5å·´é¡¿å¼•ç”¨äº†äº¨åˆ©Â·å¸ƒé²å…‹çº³1866å¹´çš„ç”»ä½œã€Šç¦å‰è°·çš„ç¥ˆç¥·ã€‹ï¼Œè¿™å¹…ç”»ä¹Ÿæ›¾å‡ºçŽ°åœ¨1928å¹´çš„ç¾Žå›½é‚®ç¥¨ä¸Šã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œæ­£å¦‚åŽ†å²å­¦å®¶çº¦ç¿°Â·è´¹äºšæ‰€æŒ‡å‡ºçš„ï¼Œè¿™å¹…ç”»æ‰€ä¾æ®çš„æ•…äº‹â€œå¾ˆå¯èƒ½å¹¶æœªå‘ç”Ÿâ€ã€‚å‚è§çº¦ç¿°Â·è´¹äºšï¼Œã€Šç¾Žå›½æ˜¯ä½œä¸ºåŸºç£æ•™å›½å®¶å»ºç«‹çš„å—ï¼Ÿ ã€‹ ï¼ˆè‚¯å¡”åŸºå·žè·¯æ˜“æ–¯ç»´å°”ï¼šå¨æ–¯æ•æ–¯ç‰¹Â·çº¦ç¿°Â·è¯ºå…‹æ–¯å‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾ï¼Œ2011å¹´ï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬172é¡µã€‚å¦è§çº¦ç¿°Â·è´¹äºšçš„ä¼˜ç§€è‘—ä½œã€Šä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¦å­¦ä¹ åŽ†å²ï¼Ÿ ã€‹ ï¼ˆå¯†æ­‡æ ¹å·žè‰¾è¾¾ï¼šè´å…‹å­¦æœ¯å‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾ï¼Œ2013å¹´ï¼‰ã€‚

5 Barton uses Henry Bruecknerâ€™s 1866 painting, The Prayer at Valley Forge, which also appeared on a 1928 United States postage stamp. However, as historian John Fea notes, the account on which this painting is based â€œprobably did not happen.â€ John Fea, Was America Founded as a Christian Nation? (Louisville, KY: Westminster John Knox Press, 2011), 172. See as well John Feaâ€™s excellent Why Learn History? (Ada, MI: Baker Academic, 2013).

6 Sarah Palin äºŽ2010 å¹´ 5 æœˆ 7 æ—¥åœ¨çº½çº¦ç¦å…‹æ–¯æ–°é—»çš„ã€Šå¥¥èŽ±åˆ©å®žæƒ…ã€‹èŠ‚ç›®ä¸­å¯¹ Bill O'Reilly è¯´é“ï¼›å¼•è‡ª Jill Lepore çš„ã€Šä»–ä»¬çš„ç™½çœ¼ï¼šèŒ¶å…šé©å‘½ä¸Žç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²ä¹‹æˆ˜ã€‹ï¼ˆæ–°æ³½è¥¿å·žæ™®æž—æ–¯é¡¿ï¼šæ™®æž—æ–¯é¡¿å¤§å­¦å‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾ï¼Œ2010 å¹´ï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬ 157 é¡µã€‚

8å‚è§ Eli Gottlieb å’Œ Sam Wineburgï¼Œâ€œåœ¨çœŸç†ä¸Žå…±åŒä½“ä¹‹é—´ï¼šå­¦æœ¯å²ä¸Žç¥žåœ£å²é˜…è¯»ä¸­çš„è®¤çŸ¥è½¬æ¢â€ï¼Œã€Šå­¦ä¹ ç§‘å­¦æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 21 (2012): 84â€“129ï¼›ä»¥åŠ Sam Wineburg å’Œ Eli Gottliebï¼Œâ€œåŽ†å²å­¦å®¶é‡è§æ„Ÿæ©èŠ‚ï¼šä¹”æ²»ä¼šæ€Žä¹ˆåšï¼Ÿâ€ï¼Œã€ŠåŽ†å²å­¦ã€‹ 12 (2011): 6â€“8ã€‚

CHAPTER SIX

1ä¼—è®®å‘˜çº¦ç¿°Â·BÂ·åº·å…°ï¼Œå¼•è‡ªå½¼å¾—Â·BÂ·é“ï¼Œã€Šå­¦æ ¡æ”¿æ²»ï¼šæ¥è‡ªäººé€ å«æ˜Ÿæ—¶ä»£çš„æ•™è®­ã€‹ï¼ˆé©¬è¨è¯¸å¡žå·žå‰‘æ¡¥ï¼šå“ˆä½›å¤§å­¦å‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾ï¼Œ1991 å¹´ï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬ 200 é¡µã€‚

10æœ¬å•å…ƒçš„è¯¾ç¨‹ææ–™æ”¶å½•äºŽ Sam Wineburgã€Daisy Martin å’Œ Chauncey Monte-Sano åˆè‘—çš„ã€ŠåƒåŽ†å²å­¦å®¶ä¸€æ ·é˜…è¯»ï¼šä¸­å­¦è¯¾å ‚è¯»å†™æ•™å­¦ã€‹ï¼ˆç¬¬äºŒç‰ˆï¼Œçº½çº¦ï¼šæ•™å¸ˆå­¦é™¢å‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾ï¼Œ2012 å¹´ï¼‰ã€‚å‘å­¦ç”Ÿä»‹ç»åä¸ƒä¸–çºªçš„åŽŸå§‹èµ„æ–™è¿™å¸¦æ¥äº†ä¸€ä¸ªä¸¤éš¾çš„å¢ƒåœ°ã€‚å¦‚æžœå°†æ•™æè°ƒæ•´åˆ°äº”å¹´çº§å­¦ç”Ÿçš„é˜…è¯»æ°´å¹³ï¼Œå‡ ä¹Žæ‰€æœ‰1900å¹´ä»¥å‰çš„æ–‡çŒ®éƒ½ä¼šè¢«å‰”é™¤â€”â€”è¿™ä¸ä»…ä¼šè®©å­¦ç”Ÿæ²‰æººäºŽæž¯ç‡¥ä¹å‘³çš„æ•™ç§‘ä¹¦ï¼Œè¿˜ä¼šå‰¥å¤ºä»–ä»¬æŽ¥è§¦ä¸åŒåŽ†å²äººç‰©å£°éŸ³çš„æœºä¼šã€‚å¦ä¸€æ–¹é¢ï¼Œå¦‚æžœæˆ‘ä»¬ä¿®æ”¹åŽŸå§‹æ–‡çŒ®ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚è§„èŒƒæ‹¼å†™å’Œå¤§å°å†™ï¼Œå¹¶æœ‰é€‰æ‹©åœ°ç”¨â€œé€šä¿—æ˜“æ‡‚â€çš„è¯æ±‡æ›¿æ¢å¤è€çš„è¯æ±‡ï¼Œè¿™äº›æ–‡æœ¬è¿˜èƒ½è¢«è§†ä¸ºåŽŸå§‹æ–‡çŒ®å—ï¼Ÿåœ¨ä¿®æ”¹æ–‡çŒ®çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å€Ÿé‰´äº†â€œæ”¯æž¶å¼æ•™å­¦â€çš„æ¦‚å¿µã€‚è¿™ä¸€æ¦‚å¿µç”±ä¿„å›½å¿ƒç†å­¦å®¶åˆ—å¤«Â·ç»´æžœèŒ¨åŸºæå‡ºï¼Œä»–è®¤ä¸ºï¼Œå°†æ•™å­¦å†…å®¹ä¸Žå­¦ç”Ÿçš„è®¤çŸ¥å‘å±•æ°´å¹³ç›¸åŒ¹é…ä¼šæŸç¼šä»–ä»¬çš„å‘å±•ã€‚ç›¸åï¼Œæ•™å­¦åº”è¯¥å¼•å¯¼å­¦ç”Ÿçš„å‘å±•ã€‚é€šè¿‡å°†æ–‡çŒ®æ‘˜å½•æˆæ˜“äºŽç†è§£çš„å°æ®µï¼ˆä¸è¶…è¿‡ä¸€é¡µï¼Œ16å·å­—ä½“ï¼Œç•™ç™½è¾ƒå¤šï¼‰ï¼Œå¹¶å¯¹æ‹¼å†™ã€å¤§å°å†™å’Œè¯æ±‡è¿›è¡Œç»†å¾®æ”¹åŠ¨ï¼ˆä½†åŠ›æ±‚ä¿ç•™è¿‘å››ç™¾å¹´å‰è¯­è¨€çš„éŸµå¾‹ï¼‰ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åˆ›å»ºäº†ä¸€ä¸ªæ¡£æ¡ˆåº“ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­å……æ»¡äº†æŒ‘æˆ˜é’å°‘å¹´ä½†åˆä¸è‡³äºŽè®©ä»–ä»¬æ„Ÿåˆ°ä¸çŸ¥æ‰€æŽªçš„å£°éŸ³ã€‚å…³äºŽè¿™ç§æ–¹æ³•çš„æ›´å¤šä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œè¯·å‚é˜… Sam Wineburg å’Œ Daisy Martin çš„æ–‡ç« â€œTampering with History: Adapting Primary Sources for Struggling Readersâ€ï¼Œè½½äºŽã€Šç¤¾ä¼šæ•™è‚²ã€‹ 73 å· 5 æœŸï¼ˆ2009 å¹´ï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬ 212-216 é¡µã€‚

10 The curriculum materials we assembled for this unit appear in Sam Wineburg, Daisy Martin, and Chauncey Monte-Sano, Reading Like a Historian: Teaching Literacy in Middle and High School Classroom, 2nd ed. (New York: Teachers College Press, 2012). Presenting seventeenth-century primary sources to students posed a dilemma. Matching materials to fifth-gradersâ€™ reading level would eliminate practically every document written before 1900â€”not only sentencing students to the textbookâ€™s gruel but depriving them of the experience of encountering multiple voices from historical actors. On the other hand, were we to tamper with primary documents by conventionalizing spelling and capitalization and selectively replacing archaic vocabulary with â€œaccessibleâ€ words, would these texts still be considered primary? As we modified documents, our decisions were informed by notions of scaffolding, a concept developed by Russian psychologist Lev Vygotsky, who argued that matching instruction to studentsâ€™ developmental levels shackled them. Rather, instruction should lead development. By excerpting documents into manageable chunks (no more than a page long, with sixteen-point print and lots of white space) and making slight changes in spelling, capitalization, and vocabulary (but making every effort to retain the cadence of a language written nearly four hundred years before), we created an archive filled with voices that challenged these youngsters but did not overwhelm them. For more on this approach, see Sam Wineburg and Daisy Martin, â€œTampering with History: Adapting Primary Sources for Struggling Readers,â€ Social Education 73, no. 5 (2009): 212â€“16.

11çº¦ç¿°Â·å²å¯†æ–¯ï¼Œã€Šå¼—å‰å°¼äºšè‡ªå»ºç«‹æ®–æ°‘åœ°ä»¥æ¥å‘ç”Ÿçš„å€¼å¾—æ³¨æ„çš„äº‹ä»¶å’Œäº‹æ•…çš„çœŸå®žè®°è¿°ã€‹ï¼ˆ1608 å¹´ï¼‰ï¼Œâ€œç¬¬ä¸€æ‰‹èµ„æ–™â€ï¼Œè™šæ‹Ÿè©¹å§†æ–¯æ•¦ï¼Œhttp://www.virtualjamestown.org/exist/cocoon/jamestown/fha/J1007ã€‚

11 John Smith, â€œA True Relation of Such Occurrences and Accidents of Note as Hath Hapned in Virginia Since the First Planting of that Colonyâ€ (1608), â€œFirst Hand Accounts,â€ Virtual Jamestown, http://www.virtualjamestown.org/exist/cocoon/jamestown/fha/J1007.

12çº¦ç¿°Â·å²å¯†æ–¯ï¼Œã€Šå¼—å‰å°¼äºšã€æ–°è‹±æ ¼å…°å’Œå¤å²›é€šå²ã€‹ï¼ˆ1607 å¹´ï¼‰ï¼Œç¾Žå›½å›½ä¼šå›¾ä¹¦é¦†ï¼Œhttps://www.loc.gov/resource/lhbcb.0262a/? sp= 136ã€‚

34.åœ¨ç ”ç©¶è¿›è¡Œåˆ°ä¸€åŠæ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æŠŠoccupytheory.orgä»»åŠ¡åŠ å…¥åˆ°ç ”ç©¶æ–¹æ¡ˆä¸­ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬è§‚å¯Ÿäº†äº”ä½åŽ†å²å­¦å®¶ï¼Œä½†ä»–ä»¬éƒ½æ²¡èƒ½æ‰¾åˆ°Brandon Gailleçš„åå­—ã€‚åœ¨25åæœ¬ç§‘ç”Ÿä¸­ï¼Œæœ€ç»ˆåªæœ‰ä¸€äººæ‰¾åˆ°äº†ï¼›å¦æœ‰ä¸¤äººæ‰¾åˆ°äº†Gailleçš„åå­—ï¼Œä½†å¹¶æ²¡æœ‰å®Œå…¨è®¤å‡ºä»–ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ²¡æœ‰ç¡®å®šä»–æ˜¯å¦æ˜¯è¯¥ç½‘ç«™çš„æ‰€æœ‰è€…å’Œ/æˆ–åˆ›å»ºè€…ã€‚

34 The occupytheory.org task was added to our protocol halfway through our study. Five historians were observed; none came close to locating the name of Brandon Gaille. 47åª’ä½“ä¸“å®¶ä»¬å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå–œæ¬¢åšçš„æ´»åŠ¨æ˜¯å¼•å¯¼å­¦ç”Ÿè®¿é—®ä¸€äº›ä¸“é—¨è®¾è®¡çš„è™šå‡ç½‘ç«™ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚â€œå¤ªå¹³æ´‹è¥¿åŒ—æ ‘ç« é±¼â€ï¼ˆhttp://zapatopi.net/treeoctopus/ï¼‰ã€‚ä»–ä»¬å¸Œæœ›å­¦ç”Ÿæ„è¯†åˆ°è‡ªå·±å¾ˆå®¹æ˜“ä¸Šå½“å—éª—åŽï¼Œèƒ½å¤Ÿæé«˜åª’ä½“ç´ å…»ã€‚é—®é¢˜åœ¨äºŽï¼Œè™šå‡ä¿¡æ¯åœ¨ç½‘ç»œå†…å®¹ä¸­åªå æžå°ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼›å¦‚æžœæŠŠæ³¨æ„åŠ›é›†ä¸­åœ¨è™šå‡ä¿¡æ¯ä¸Šï¼Œå°±ä¼šç»™äººä¸€ç§é”™è§‰ï¼Œè®¤ä¸ºå»ºç«‹å¯ä¿¡åº¦å°±åƒéžæ­¤å³å½¼ä¸€æ ·ç®€å•ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åº”è¯¥æ•™å¯¼å­¦ç”Ÿçš„æ˜¯ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªä¸Žç¤¾ä¼šç›¸å…³çš„ç½‘ç«™éƒ½æœ‰å…¶ç«‹åœºï¼Œå…¶ç›®çš„éƒ½æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†èµ¢å¾—äººå¿ƒï¼ŒèŽ·å¾—è¿½éšè€…ã€‚

47 Another favorite activity of media specialists is to direct students to specially designed hoax websites such as the â€œPacific Northwest Tree Octopusâ€ (http://zapatopi.net/treeoctopus/). The hope is that when students realize how easily theyâ€™re duped, theyâ€™ll become more media savvy. The problem is that hoaxes constitute a minuscule fraction of what exists on the Web; focusing attention on them creates the impression that establishing credibility is as simple as an either/or. We should instead be teaching students that every site about the social world has a stance, with the goal of winning hearts and gaining adherents.

48 James O'Brienï¼Œâ€œåª’ä½“çƒ­è®®çš„å››ç§åŽŸç”Ÿå¹¿å‘Šâ€ï¼ŒMashableï¼Œ2014å¹´9æœˆ30æ—¥ï¼Œhttp://mashable.com/2014/09/30/native-ad-campaigns/#yEtyTTA01aqKã€‚è®°è€…ã€å¹¿å‘Šå•†å’Œå…¬å…³ä¸»ç®¡éƒ½æ‰¿è®¤ï¼ŒåŽŸç”Ÿå¹¿å‘Šçš„æœ¬è´¨æ˜¯æ¬ºéª—ã€‚Erin E. 48 James Oâ€™Brien, â€œFour Native Ads the Mediaâ€™s Talking About,â€ Mashable, September 30, 2014, http://mashable.com/2014/09/30/native-ad-campaigns/#yEtyTTA01aqK. That the essence of native advertising is deception is conceded by journalists, advertising, and public relations executives. Erin E. Schauster, Patrick Ferrucci, and Marlene S. Neill, â€œNative Advertising Is the New Journalism: How Deception Affects Social Responsibility,â€ American Behavioral Scientist 60 (2016): 1408â€“24.

53å‚è§ Joseph Kahne å’Œ Benjamin Bowyerï¼Œâ€œåœ¨å…šæ´¾æ—¶ä»£è¿›è¡Œæ°‘ä¸»æ•™è‚²ï¼šåº”å¯¹åŠ¨æœºæŽ¨ç†å’Œé”™è¯¯ä¿¡æ¯çš„æŒ‘æˆ˜â€ï¼Œã€Šç¾Žå›½æ•™è‚²ç ”ç©¶æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 54 (2017): 3â€“34ã€‚

53 See Joseph Kahne and Benjamin Bowyer, â€œEducating for Democracy in a Partisan Age: Confronting the Challenges of Motivated Reasoning and Misinformation,â€ American Education Research Journal 54 (2017): 3â€“34.

54æˆ‘å€Ÿç”¨äº†çº¦ç¿°Â·HÂ·éº¦å…‹é©¬çº³æ–¯åœ¨å…¶ä¸å¯æˆ–ç¼ºçš„è‘—ä½œã€Šè¯†ç ´è°Žè¨€ï¼šå¦‚ä½•è¯†åˆ«å°åˆ·å“ã€å¹¿æ’­å’Œç½‘ç»œä¸Šçš„åè§å’Œåžƒåœ¾æ–°é—»ã€‹ï¼ˆç¬¬äºŒç‰ˆï¼ŒåŠ åˆ©ç¦å°¼äºšå·žæ¡‘å°¼ç»´å°”ï¼šUnvarnished Pressï¼Œ2012 å¹´ï¼‰ä¸­æ‰©å±•é˜è¿°çš„è¿™ä¸€è§‚ç‚¹ã€‚

54 I borrow this point, which was made in an expanded form, from John H. McManusâ€™s indispensable Detecting Bull: How to Identify Bias and Junk Journalism in Print, Broadcast and on the Wild Web, 2nd ed. (Sunnyvale, CA: Unvarnished Press, 2012).

55æ‰˜é©¬æ–¯Â·æ°æ–é€Šè‡´å¨å»‰Â·æŸ¥å°”æ–¯Â·è´¾ç»´æ–¯çš„ä¿¡ï¼Œ1820 å¹´ 9 æœˆ 28 æ—¥ã€‚å›½å®¶æ¡£æ¡ˆé¦†ï¼Œhttps://archive.org/stream/writingsofthomas10jeffiala/writingsofthomas10jeffiala_djvu.txtã€‚

55 Thomas Jefferson, letter to William Charles Jarvis, September 28, 1820. National Archives, https://archive.org/stream/writingsofthomas10jeffiala/writingsofthomas10jeffiala_djvu.txt.

ç¬¬å…«ç« 

CHAPTER EIGHT

1æœ¬ç« çš„æ›´é•¿æ›´è¯¦ç»†çš„ç‰ˆæœ¬ä»¥ Sam Wineburg å’Œ Chauncey Monte-Sano çš„æ–‡ç« â€œâ€˜è‘—åç¾Žå›½äººâ€™ï¼šç¾Žå›½è‹±é›„ä¸‡ç¥žæ®¿çš„å˜è¿â€å‘è¡¨äºŽã€Šç¾Žå›½åŽ†å²æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 94ï¼ˆ2008 å¹´ 3 æœˆï¼‰ï¼š1186â€“202ï¼›æœ¬ç« æ‰€ä¾æ®çš„è¾ƒçŸ­ç‰ˆæœ¬ä»¥ Sam Wineburg çš„æ–‡ç« â€œå†è§ï¼Œå“¥ä¼¦å¸ƒâ€å‘è¡¨äºŽã€Šå²å¯†æ£®å°¼æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 39ï¼ˆ2008 å¹´ï¼‰ï¼š98â€“104ã€‚

1 A longer and more detailed version of this chapter appeared as Sam Wineburg and Chauncey Monte-Sano, â€œâ€˜Famous Americansâ€™: The Changing Pantheon of American Heroes,â€ Journal of American History 94 (March 2008): 1186â€“202; a shorter version, on which this chapter is based, appeared as Sam Wineburg, â€œGoodbye, Columbus,â€ Smithsonian Magazine 39 (2008): 98â€“104.

2æˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ ·æœ¬é™åˆ¶ä¸ºç¾Žå›½å‡ºç”Ÿçš„æˆå¹´äººï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿å°†åœ¨ç¾Žå›½æŽ¥å—æ•™è‚²çš„å¹´è½»äººä¸Žä¸€ç»„æŽ¥å—ç±»ä¼¼æ•™è‚²çš„æˆå¹´äººè¿›è¡Œæ¯”è¾ƒã€‚

2 We restricted our sample to American-born adults so we could compare young people, schooled in the United States, with a group of adults similarly schooled.

3 Frances FitzGeraldï¼Œã€Šç¾Žå›½ä¿®è®¢ç‰ˆï¼šäºŒåä¸–çºªåŽ†å²æ•™ç§‘ä¹¦ã€‹ï¼ˆçº½çº¦ï¼šLittle, Brownï¼Œ1979 å¹´ï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬ 84 é¡µã€‚FitzGerald åœ¨ David Saville Muzzey çš„ã€Šæˆ‘ä»¬å›½å®¶çš„åŽ†å²ï¼šé«˜ä¸­ç”Ÿæ•™ç§‘ä¹¦ã€‹ ï¼ˆæ³¢å£«é¡¿ï¼šGinn and Co.ï¼Œ1950 å¹´ï¼‰çš„å¼•è¨€ç¬¬ 3 é¡µä¸­æ‰¾åˆ°äº†â€œæ’‡å¼€é»‘äººå’Œå°ç¬¬å®‰äººäººå£â€è¿™ä¸€æ¡æ¬¾ã€‚

6å‚è§ Fergus M. 11å¤§å«Â·å“ˆä¼¯æ–¯å¦å§†ï¼Œã€Šé©¬ä¸Â·è·¯å¾·Â·é‡‘çš„ç¬¬äºŒæ¬¡é™ä¸´ã€‹ï¼Œã€Šå“ˆç€æ–¯æ‚å¿—ã€‹ 235ï¼ˆ1967 å¹´ 8 æœˆï¼‰ï¼š48ã€‚â€œä¸‰é‡é‚ªæ¶â€çš„å¼•æ–‡å‡ºè‡ªé‡‘åœ¨ 1967 å¹´ 8 æœˆ 16 æ—¥å—æ–¹åŸºç£æ•™é¢†è¢–ä¼šè®®ä¸Šçš„æœ€åŽä¸€æ¬¡æ¼”è®²ã€‚é©¬ä¸Â·è·¯å¾·Â·é‡‘ï¼Œã€Šæˆ‘ä»¬ä½•åŽ»ä½•ä»Žï¼Ÿã€‹ï¼Œè½½äºŽã€Šå¸Œæœ›çš„è§è¯ï¼šé©¬ä¸Â·è·¯å¾·Â·é‡‘çš„ç²¾é€‰è‘—ä½œã€‹ï¼Œè©¹å§†æ–¯Â·æ¢…å°”æ–‡Â·åŽç››é¡¿ç¼–ï¼ˆæ—§é‡‘å±±ï¼šå“ˆç€å‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾ï¼Œ1986 å¹´ï¼‰ï¼Œ250ï¼›æœ‰å…³è¶Šå—æˆ˜äº‰å’Œæˆ˜äº‰ç½ªè¡Œçš„å¼•è¨€ï¼Œè¯·å‚é˜…é©¬ä¸Â·è·¯å¾·Â·é‡‘ (Martin Luther King Jr.) çš„ã€Šé¼“æ‰‹æœ¬èƒ½ã€‹(Drum Major Instinct)ï¼Œ1968 å¹´ 2 æœˆ 4 æ—¥åœ¨åŸƒæ¯”å°¼æ³½æµ¸ä¿¡ä¼šæ•™å ‚ (Ebenezer Baptist Church) å‘è¡¨çš„å¸ƒé“ï¼Œæ–¯å¦ç¦å¤§å­¦é©¬ä¸Â·è·¯å¾·Â·é‡‘ç ”ç©¶ä¸Žæ•™è‚²ç ”ç©¶æ‰€ (The Martin Luther King, Jr., Research and Education Institute, Stanford University)ï¼Œhttp://kingencyclopedia.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/documentsentry/doc_the_drum_major_instinct/ã€‚
